2D and corrugated 2D organometallic halide perovskites are
formed by splitting along lattice orientations
from 3D perovskites, which are identified as Ruddlesden–
formula of 2D organometallic halide perovskites is (A
large aliphatic alkyl chain or an aromatic ligand) and acts as
an insulating layer to isolate the different inorganic layers
that are composed of metal halide octahedral units shared
through corner atoms. A represents small cations, such as
. B is a divalent metal cation (Pb
and X refers to halides. Symbol
metal halide monolayer sheets in between the insulating A
the single ammonium cations, the terminal amine of organic
cation interacts with halide of inorganic anion layer through
hydrogen bonds, and the adjacent carbon chains of the organic
cations are bound together by van der Waals force to form
organic layers. For the diammonium cations, the two terminal
amines are linked to the inorganic layer through hydrogen
2D perovskites are considered as active optoelectronic
materials for optoelectronic devices due to their large exciton
Ruddlesden–Popper perovskites with a formula of (A
recently gained widespread interest as candidates for the next generation of
optoelectronic devices. The variations of organic cation, metal halide, and
the number of layers in the structure lead to the change of crystal structures
and properties for different optoelectronic applications. Herein, the different
synthetic methods for 2D perovskite crystals and thin films are summarized
and compared. The optoelectronic properties and the charge transfer process
in the devices are also delved, in particular, for light-emitting diodes and solar
